Ranking evaluation metrics from a
group-theoretic perspective

Chiara Balestra
TU Dortmund
Germany
&Andreas Mayr
IMBIE, University Hospital of Bonn
Germany
&Emmanuel Müller
TU Dortmund
Germany
This research was supported by the research training group \csq@thequote@oinit\csq@thequote@oopenDataninja\csq@thequote@oclose (Trustworthy AI for Seamless Problem Solving: Next Generation Intelligence Joins Robust Data Analysis) funded by the German federal state of North Rhine-Westphalia.
Abstract

Confronted with the challenge of identifying the most suitable metric to validate the merits of newly proposed models, the decision-making process is anything but straightforward. Given that comparing rankings introduces its own set of formidable challenges and the likely absence of a universal metric applicable to all scenarios, the scenario does not get any better. Furthermore, metrics designed for specific contexts, such as for Recommender Systems, sometimes extend to other domains without a comprehensive grasp of their underlying mechanisms, resulting in unforeseen outcomes and potential misuses. Complicating matters further, distinct metrics may emphasize different aspects of rankings, frequently leading to seemingly contradictory comparisons of model results and hindering the trustworthiness of evaluations.

We unveil these aspects in the domain of ranking evaluation metrics. Firstly, we show instances resulting in inconsistent evaluations, sources of potential mistrust in commonly used metrics; by quantifying the frequency of such disagreements, we prove that these are common in rankings. Afterward, we conceptualize rankings using the mathematical formalism of symmetric groups detaching from possible domains where the metrics have been created; through this approach, we can rigorously and formally establish essential mathematical properties for ranking evaluation metrics, essential for a deeper comprehension of the source of inconsistent evaluations. We conclude with a discussion, connecting our theoretical analysis to the practical applications, highlighting which properties are important in each domain where rankings are commonly evaluated. In conclusion, our analysis sheds light on ranking evaluation metrics, highlighting that inconsistent evaluations should not be seen as a source of mistrust but as the need to carefully choose how to evaluate our models in the future.

1 Introduction

Evaluating methods is fundamental in any machine learning field, but it is not straightforward finding an appropriate evaluation metric that accurately assesses a method’s strengths without unfairly biasing comparisons to other approaches. Comparing rankings is particularly challenging: inconsistencies often appear in the produced evaluations, and, notably, inconsistencies diminish users’ trust in the methods and evaluations.

Rankings pop up in several domains, from Recommender Systems (RS) and Information Retrieval (IR) techniques [1, 20], to feature ranking and selection approaches [17] as well as in (fair) rank aggregation methods [18]. They are looked at as “interpretable” and easy to understand by humans; as an example, let us think about a scoring system that represents job applicants’ characteristics, where a high score is an indicator of a better fit for the position. However, evaluating rankings is not at all that simple, and contradictory evaluations are commonplace. Furthermore, several metrics are appropriately created to evaluate, for example, Recommender Systems or rank aggregation approaches; however, the same metrics are often used in other contexts without a sufficient understanding of their evaluation.

First, we show the existence of inconsistencies among most pairs of metrics; given the frequency of inconsistencies’ occurrences, evaluations of methods involving rankings are often not trustworthy. We then introduce a list of desirable theoretical properties for ranking evaluation metrics and provide the mathematical framework underpinning each of them; rankings metrics can be easily transferred to functions on mathematical groups, specifically on symmetric groups, thus allowing us to detach from specific machine learning domains. The choice is dictated by the fact that they represent the most general mathematical structure on which we could represent rankings. Profiting from a strong mathematical theoretical interface, we look to answer the question which mathematical properties are essential for evaluating rankings? Thus, while most of the existing literature predominantly confines itself rather to narrow, highly specific contexts, our work provides a theoretical framework beyond specific contexts of application. We further assert that almost none of the metrics qualifies as a mathematical distance, as fundamental characteristics are not satisfied. Although symmetric groups offer a broad generalization, we remain mindful of the specific contexts in which the metrics were developed. We highlight the contexts where these properties are particularly valuable in a conclusive discussion.

2 Related work

The literature on ranking evaluation metrics is mostly highly context-specific. Particularly developed for RS and IR evaluation, we find several works exploring the relationships among the metrics [24, 10, 22]. [13] proposes a theoretical division of the metrics for comparing collaborative filtering RS, while [19] describes most of the metrics typically used for RS and IR techniques. [15] presents various metrics based on cumulative gain, highlighting their main advantages and drawbacks, [14] introduces a theoretical foundation for rank-based evaluation metrics, and [2] defines a set of properties for IR metrics and shows that none of the existing ones satisfy all the properties proposed. Other works focus on metrics for RS and their intrinsic properties or on ranking metrics for the top-n𝑛nitalic_n recommendations [3, 25]. Real-world applications such as the design of strategies based on customers’ feedback and allocation of priorities in R&D extended the interest in defining distances among rankings where the focus of the problem statement is rank aggregation [6, 21]. Examples of similarly scoped works are [4, 7]. An interesting generalization work is presented by [5], that focuses on six metrics on symmetric groups; we find among them, Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ and Spearmann’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ while the other considered metrics are rather uncommon in machine learning. The work studies them from a statistical and theoretical perspective and defines some properties, among which the interpretability, tractability, sensitivity, i.e., the ability of one metric to range among the available counter-domain, and theoretical availability. In detail, the interpretability defined in [5] discussed whether the metrics measure something humanly tangible, the tractability studies the so-called computational complexity in computer science, and the theoretical availability asks whether a metric is studied and used enough in the state-of-the-art works. We will reintroduce one of the properties in [5], e.g., the right-invariance, in our work into our Robustness property.

The interest in fair and trusted choices of evaluation metrics grows fast in computer science. [23] is an example where some of the ranking evaluation metrics are harshly criticized for their comparisons’ reliability. In other domains, the state-of-the-art literature started defining essential properties for metrics [8, 9]; we aim to fill the gap for ranking evaluation metrics.

3 Metrics

In the state-of-the-art literature, we find various metrics meant to evaluate ranking in specific contexts. This is the case for most offline Recommender Systems metrics, some evaluation metrics for prediction models, and rank aggregation approaches. Some of these metrics started spreading to other domains following the need to evaluate rankings. However, this is not always a good idea as the domain defines the evaluation’s exigencies. In our work, we consider metrics evaluating full rankings that can be easily transferred to adjacent domains and cut out from the analysis all those metrics that require context-specific information, e.g., diversity in Recommender Systems. We refer to the group as ranking evaluation metrics; a complete list is summarized in Table 1.

We categorize the ranking evaluation metrics under two different theoretical aspects. One subdivision derives from their “awareness” of the position of single items in the rankings: Ranking aware metrics satisfy this criterion while flat metrics do not. In this second group, we find the set-based metrics and the ones assigning equal importance to each position. The subdivision is shown in Figure 1 on the right. From their theoretical definition, we individuate four main groups: confusion matrix-based CMB metrics focus on the number of correctly retrieved elements and are essentially set-based metrics; correlation-based CB metrics quantify the ordinal association between the two rankings from a statistical perspective; error-based EB metrics are often used to analyze the performance of predicting models and are flat metrics assigning equal importance to each position; Finally, cumulative gain-based CGB metrics focus on the rankings of the single elements; additional explanations on how the single metrics have been classified and the definition of the single metrics are available in Appendix B.

4.1 Clustering by agreement

Our work is mainly justified by the lack of “consistent” evaluation of rankings when using different metrics. A ranking evaluation metric is a function m:Sn×Sn→ℝ+:𝑚→subscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛subscriptℝm:S_{n}\times S_{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_m : italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, taking two permutations as input and returning a real number. In some cases, metrics take only one ranking as input; we refer to them as single input metrics. All the given definitions work correspondingly for one-input metrics.

Proving consistency between two metrics is much trickier than finding three rankings satisfying the inconsistency condition; therefore, rather than classify them, we estimate the degree of inconsistency among pairs of metrics by introducing the agreement ratio. The coefficient provides an estimate of the extent to which two metrics disagree in the evaluation of rankings over symmetric groups.

5 Properties for ranking evaluation metrics

Most pairs of metrics are affected by frequent inconsistent evaluations (cf. Section 4.1). We list essential mathematical properties to highlight the peculiarity of each metric and give the chance to properly select one or another based on them for a context-dependent evaluation. The properties in question are: (1) identity of indiscernibles (IoI); (2) symmetry (or independence from a ground truth); (3) robustness (Type-I and Type-II); (4) stability with respect to k𝑘kitalic_k; (5) sensitivity and width-swap-dependency; (6) (induced) distance. Some of them have been defined in other domains, wee.g., [9, 8] define the symmetry property for cluster similarity indices and metrics for classification models, [12] defines the “resistance to relabeling” in the context of rank aggregation, [4, 7] define the importance of constructing distances for partial orderings; will refer to each of them in the respective sections.

For each property, we will highlight in which context and why it is important. Table 3 and Table 4 help the reader to keep trace of the mentioned results. The code will be on GitHub upon acceptance 111https://github.com/chiarabales/rankingsEvalMetrics.

5.1 Identity of indiscernibles

Ideally, a metric m𝑚mitalic_m quantifies how “close” or “similar” two rankings σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ are. However, situations may arise where σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ are “so” similar to be practically indistinguishable by some metrics. This effect might be undesired in some fields, such as (fair) rank aggregation, where even small differences, especially in the presence of protected groups, make the difference between fair and unfair rankings.

Definition 3.

A metric m𝑚mitalic_m satisfies the identity of indiscernible (IoI) property if, ∀σ∈Snfor-all𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛\forall\sigma\in S_{n}∀ italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT fixed, the following holds

m⁢(σ,τ)=m⁢(σ,ν)⇔τ=ν,∀τ,ν∈Sn.⇔𝑚𝜎𝜏𝑚𝜎𝜈formulae-sequence𝜏𝜈for-all𝜏𝜈subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\tau)=m(\sigma,\nu)\Leftrightarrow\tau=\nu,\qquad\forall\tau,\nu\in S% _{n}.italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_τ ) = italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) ⇔ italic_τ = italic_ν , ∀ italic_τ , italic_ν ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (4)

Up to renaming the elements, we can rewrite Equation equation 4 as m⁢(id,τ)=m⁢(id,ν)⇔ν=τ⇔𝑚id𝜏𝑚id𝜈𝜈𝜏m(\text{id},\tau)=m(\text{id},\nu)\Leftrightarrow\nu=\tauitalic_m ( id , italic_τ ) = italic_m ( id , italic_ν ) ⇔ italic_ν = italic_τ where id is the usual identity of Snsubscript𝑆𝑛S_{n}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Almost all metrics do not satisfy the IoI property; examples are set-based metrics and metrics@k, i.e., where a metric m@⁢ksubscript𝑚@𝑘m_{@k}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT @ italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT evaluates only the top k𝑘kitalic_k elements of the rankings . Clear examples not satisfying equation 4 are rankings σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ that can be written as a disjoint composition of cycles of permutations of elements before and after k𝑘kitalic_k [11]. Table 2 illustrates examples for each metric where the IoI is not satisfied. It can be proven that

Proposition 5.1.

DCG and nDCG satisfy the IoI property.

The proof finds place in Appendix A.

5.2 Symmetry property

Often, guarantees that the evaluation is symmetric with respect to input items are desirable [8, 9], particularly when the interest is in having a sort of mathematical distance, e.g., for rank aggregation. However, as usual, the context rules the need for a symmetric evaluation. The symmetry property studies whether the metric’s evaluation is independent of the order in which the rankings are compared. In RS and IR, the common presence of a “ground truth order” makes the symmetric property impossible.

Definition 4.

A metric m:Sn×Sn→ℝ:𝑚→subscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛ℝm:S_{n}\times S_{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_m : italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → blackboard_R is symmetric if

m⁢(σ,ν)=m⁢(ν,σ),∀σ,ν∈Sn.formulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜈𝑚𝜈𝜎for-all𝜎𝜈subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\nu)=m(\nu,\sigma),\qquad\forall\sigma,\nu\in S_{n}.italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) = italic_m ( italic_ν , italic_σ ) , ∀ italic_σ , italic_ν ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (5)

5.3 Robustness

The IoI property studies whether metrics can distinguish rankings, regardless of their similarity. On the other side, the similarities among rankings should be projected on the evaluations: Small differences in rankings should result in small differences in the evaluation scores. Under the assumption that a single swap represents a small difference between two rankings, the Type I robustness property assesses how sensitive a ranking evaluation metric is to single swaps in the compared rankings.

Definition 5.

A metric m𝑚mitalic_m is Type I Robust if a single swap in one of the rankings implies small changes in its evaluation, i.e.,

|m(σ,ν)−m(σ,ν∘(ij)|<ϵ,∀σ,ν∈Sn.|m(\sigma,\nu)-m(\sigma,\nu\circ(i\ j)|<\epsilon,\qquad\forall\sigma,\nu\in S_% {n}.| italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) - italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ∘ ( italic_i italic_j ) | < italic_ϵ , ∀ italic_σ , italic_ν ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (6)

We compute the average of the results of equation 6 evaluated on a set ℐ⊆Sn×Snℐsubscript𝑆𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛\mathcal{I}\subseteq{S_{n}}\times{S_{n}}caligraphic_I ⊆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 1000100010001000 different randomly drawn pairs of rankings in S100subscript𝑆100S_{100}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., ∑(σ,ν)∈ℐ,(i,j)∈{1,⋯,n}2|m(σ,ν)−m(σ,ν∘(ij)|\sum_{(\sigma,\nu)\in\mathcal{I},(i,j)\in\{1,\cdots,n\}^{2}}|m(\sigma,\nu)-m(% \sigma,\nu\circ(i\ j)|∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) ∈ caligraphic_I , ( italic_i , italic_j ) ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , italic_n } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) - italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ∘ ( italic_i italic_j ) | and round it to two decimal numbers. We state that the metric satisfies the Type I Robustness if the resulting average is 00.

For completeness, we define a second type of robustness that studies the effect of renaming the items in the rankings. [5] mentions Type II Robustness as “right-invariance” and [12] as “resistance to item relabeling”.

Definition 6.

A metric is Type II Robust if it is an invariant w.r.t. the composition of permutations, i.e., it holds

m⁢(μ,σ)=m⁢(μ∘ν,σ∘ν),∀μ,σ,ν∈Sn.formulae-sequence𝑚𝜇𝜎𝑚𝜇𝜈𝜎𝜈for-all𝜇𝜎𝜈subscript𝑆𝑛m(\mu,\sigma)=m(\mu\circ\nu,\sigma\circ\nu),\forall\mu,\sigma,\nu\in S_{n}.italic_m ( italic_μ , italic_σ ) = italic_m ( italic_μ ∘ italic_ν , italic_σ ∘ italic_ν ) , ∀ italic_μ , italic_σ , italic_ν ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Type II Robustness property investigates whether applying the same change in both rankings affects the evaluation. The property is essential in contexts where the numbers appearing in the rankings have to be considered as proper “items” or “items’ names”; this is often the case in rank aggregation approaches, Recommender Systems, and Information Retrieval techniques. However, it does not apply when dealing with importance scores. We claim that

Proposition 5.2.

MSE, RMSE, MAE, MAPE, R2 score, Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ score and Spearmann’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ are the only considered metrics satisfying the Type II Robustness.

The proof derives directly from their definitions (see Appendix A).

5.4 Sensitivity

The sensitivity property is valuable for a metric, particularly in the case of Recommender Systems and Information Retrieval, where high dimensional rankings may not be fully explored. Under the assumption that a full exploration of the rankings is not possible, sensitive metrics assign more weight to the first part of the rankings, considering whether the first k𝑘kitalic_k items are “correctly” ranked. Mathematically, we define the width of a swap (i⁢j)∈Sn𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑛(i\ j)\in S_{n}( italic_i italic_j ) ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being the quantity |i−j|𝑖𝑗|i-j|| italic_i - italic_j |.

Definition 7.

Given i<j<k<l∈{1,…,n}𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑙1…𝑛i<j<k<l\in\{1,\ldots,n\}italic_i < italic_j < italic_k < italic_l ∈ { 1 , … , italic_n } and (i⁢j),(l⁢k)𝑖𝑗𝑙𝑘(i\ j),(l\ k)( italic_i italic_j ) , ( italic_l italic_k ) having the same width. A ranking evaluation metric m𝑚mitalic_m is sensitive if ∃σ∈Sn𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛\exists\sigma\in S_{n}∃ italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that it holds m⁢((i⁢j)∘σ)≠m⁢((k⁢l)∘σ)𝑚𝑖𝑗𝜎𝑚𝑘𝑙𝜎m((i\ j)\circ\sigma)\neq m((k\ l)\circ\sigma)italic_m ( ( italic_i italic_j ) ∘ italic_σ ) ≠ italic_m ( ( italic_k italic_l ) ∘ italic_σ ).

As the evaluation of the property is far from easy, we introduce the width swap dependency, formalizing a property that prevents the metrics from being sensitive.

Definition 8.

Given a swap (i⁢j)∈Sn𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑛(i\ j)\in S_{n}( italic_i italic_j ) ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and |i−j|𝑖𝑗|i-j|| italic_i - italic_j | its width, m𝑚mitalic_m is width swap dependent (WSD) if it evaluates swaps with the same width equally, i.e., m⁢((i⁢j))=m⁢((k⁢l))𝑚𝑖𝑗𝑚𝑘𝑙m((i\ j))=m((k\ l))italic_m ( ( italic_i italic_j ) ) = italic_m ( ( italic_k italic_l ) ) if |i−j|=|k−l|𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑙|i-j|=|k-l|| italic_i - italic_j | = | italic_k - italic_l | holds; otherwise, it is called non-width swap dependent.

The WSD property cuts out some of the metrics from being sensitive. From their definitions, it can be proven that

Lemma 5.3.

Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, Spearmann ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, NDPM are width swap independent.

The proof finds place in Appendix A. For the other metrics,it is trivial to find pairs of disjoint swaps had different effects in the final evaluation when happening at various positions within the rankings.

5.5 Stability

We introduce the stability property for those metrics that can be applied on “rankings @⁢k@𝑘@k@ italic_k”. We recall that a ranking at k𝑘kitalic_k is the ranking of the items in the first k𝑘kitalic_k positions. To evaluate rankings @⁢k@𝑘@k@ italic_k, it is essential that the difference between evaluations “@⁢k@𝑘@k@ italic_k” and “@⁢k+1@𝑘1@k+1@ italic_k + 1” is not significant, i.e., that the choice of k𝑘kitalic_k does not highly impact the result; this guarantees a trustworthy evaluation.

Definition 9.

A ranking evaluation metric m𝑚mitalic_m is stable if, for any two rankings σ,ν∈Sn𝜎𝜈subscript𝑆𝑛\sigma,\nu\in S_{n}italic_σ , italic_ν ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds

|m@⁢k−1⁢(σ,ν)−m@⁢k⁢(σ,ν)|<ϵksubscript𝑚@𝑘1𝜎𝜈subscript𝑚@𝑘𝜎𝜈subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\left|m_{@k-1}(\sigma,\nu)-m_{@k}(\sigma,\nu)\right|<\epsilon_{k}| italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT @ italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) - italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT @ italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) | < italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (7)

with ϵksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon_{k}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT small. Moreover, the sequence {ϵk}ksubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘𝑘\{\epsilon_{k}\}_{k}{ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies limk→nϵk=0subscript→𝑘𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘0\lim_{k\to n}\epsilon_{k}=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k → italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

The property is again essential for extremely long rankings and for contexts where rankings are not fully explored. We evaluate the stability by randomly drawing 1000100010001000 pairs of rankings in S100subscript𝑆100S_{100}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, computing the absolute differences of equation 7, and counting the number of times that equation 7 holds with ϵk=1ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘1𝑘\epsilon_{k}=\frac{1}{k}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG. We state that a metric is stable if the criterion is satisfied in at least 97.5%percent97.597.5\%97.5 % of the cases.

5.6 Distance

In mathematics, the terms metric and distance are synonyms. However, when it comes to evaluation metrics, most of them are not “distances” on Snsubscript𝑆𝑛S_{n}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the mathematical sense. Whether a metric is a mathematical distance or not is often insignificant for the final evaluations; however, being aware of this fundamental mathematical difference can avoid incomprehension and misuses.

Definition 10.

A distance on a set X𝑋Xitalic_X is a function fm:X×X→[0,∞):(x,y)↦fm⁢(x,y)∈ℝ+:subscript𝑓𝑚→𝑋𝑋0:maps-to𝑥𝑦subscript𝑓𝑚𝑥𝑦subscriptℝf_{m}:X\times X\rightarrow[0,\infty):(x,y)\mapsto f_{m}(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_X × italic_X → [ 0 , ∞ ) : ( italic_x , italic_y ) ↦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that, for all x,y,z∈X𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑋x,y,z\in Xitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z ∈ italic_X, satisfies:

  1. 1.

    fm⁢(x,y)=0⇔x=y⇔subscript𝑓𝑚𝑥𝑦0𝑥𝑦f_{m}(x,y)=0\Leftrightarrow x=yitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = 0 ⇔ italic_x = italic_y,

  2. 2.

    the positive definiteness, i.e., fm⁢(σ,ν)≥0,∀σ,ν∈Xformulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑚𝜎𝜈0for-all𝜎𝜈𝑋f_{m}(\sigma,\nu)\geq 0,\forall\sigma,\nu\in Xitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) ≥ 0 , ∀ italic_σ , italic_ν ∈ italic_X,

  3. 3.

    the symmetry property and

  4. 4.

    the triangle inequality, i.e., fm⁢(x,y)≤fm⁢(x,z)+fm⁢(z,y)subscript𝑓𝑚𝑥𝑦subscript𝑓𝑚𝑥𝑧subscript𝑓𝑚𝑧𝑦f_{m}(x,y)\leq f_{m}(x,z)+f_{m}(z,y)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) ≤ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_z ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z , italic_y ).

Some ranking evaluation metrics are distances; In [12, 5], it is proven that Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is a distance. However, a ranking evaluation metric that does not satisfy some of the properties mentioned in Definition 10 is not a distance.

We investigate if we can induce distances from single input metrics. Given a metric m:Sn→ℝ:𝑚→subscript𝑆𝑛ℝm:S_{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_m : italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → blackboard_R, we consider two options as potential induced distances, i.e., fm⁢(σ,ν)=m⁢(σ)−m⁢(ν)subscript𝑓𝑚𝜎𝜈𝑚𝜎𝑚𝜈f_{m}(\sigma,\nu)=m(\sigma)-m(\nu)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) = italic_m ( italic_σ ) - italic_m ( italic_ν ) or f~m⁢(σ,ν)=|m⁢(σ)−m⁢(ν)|subscript~𝑓𝑚𝜎𝜈𝑚𝜎𝑚𝜈\tilde{f}_{m}(\sigma,\nu)=|m(\sigma)-m(\nu)|over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) = | italic_m ( italic_σ ) - italic_m ( italic_ν ) |. DCG and nDCG are the only two metrics satisfying the IoI property that, for metrics with one unique argument, is equivalent to Property (1) for fmsubscript𝑓𝑚f_{m}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can easily prove that

Proposition 5.4.

fmsubscript𝑓𝑚f_{m}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not a distance while f~msubscript~𝑓𝑚\tilde{f}_{m}over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a distance with the IoI property, where m𝑚mitalic_m is either DCG or nDCG.

The formal proof can be found in Appendix A.

6 Are the metrics interpretable? Thoughts over maximal and minimal agreement properties

Given the importance of trust, fairness, and explainability for machine learning methods, one could then ask how “interpretable” the scores assigned by the metrics are. We first need some definitions.

Definition 11.

A ranking evaluation metric m𝑚mitalic_m is said to satisfy the maximal agreement property if (a) m⁢(σ,σ)=mmax,∀σ∈Snformulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜎subscript𝑚for-all𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\sigma)=m_{\max},\forall\sigma\in S_{n}italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_σ ) = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and (b) m⁢(σ,ν)≤mmax,∀ν,σ∈Snformulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜈subscript𝑚for-all𝜈𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\nu)\leq m_{\max},\forall\nu,\sigma\in S_{n}italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) ≤ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_ν , italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We say that m𝑚mitalic_m is lower-bounded if it exists a real number mminsubscript𝑚m_{\min}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that m⁢(σ,ν)≥mmin,∀ν,σ∈Snformulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜈subscript𝑚for-all𝜈𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\nu)\geq m_{\min},\forall\nu,\sigma\in S_{n}italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_ν ) ≥ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_ν , italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An evaluation metric that admits a lower bound is said to satisfy the minimal agreement property.

For a metric to be “interpretable” we expect that

  1. 1.

    each ranking is maximally similar to itself and, given n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}italic_n ∈ blackboard_N, this value is constant, i.e., m⁢(σ,σ)=mmax,∀σ∈Snformulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜎subscript𝑚for-all𝜎subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\sigma)=m_{\max},\forall\sigma\in S_{n}italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_σ ) = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_σ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n∀ italic_n;

  2. 2.

    m𝑚mitalic_m satisfies the maximal agreement property;

  3. 3.

    there exists a lower bound mminsubscript𝑚m_{\min}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any possible pair of rankings, i.e., m⁢(σ,μ)≥mmin,∀σ,μ∈Snformulae-sequence𝑚𝜎𝜇subscript𝑚for-all𝜎𝜇subscript𝑆𝑛m(\sigma,\mu)\geq m_{\min},\forall\sigma,\mu\in S_{n}italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_μ ) ≥ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_σ , italic_μ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Exemplary is the Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ metric which satisfies m⁢(σ,σ)=1𝑚𝜎𝜎1m(\sigma,\sigma)=1italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_σ ) = 1 and m⁢(σ,μ)∈[−1,1]𝑚𝜎𝜇11m(\sigma,\mu)\in[-1,1]italic_m ( italic_σ , italic_μ ) ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] for all σ,μ∈Sn𝜎𝜇subscript𝑆𝑛\sigma,\mu\in S_{n}italic_σ , italic_μ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The maximal agreement property says that each ranking is maximally similar to itself, and no other ranking can achieve a higher score than mmaxsubscript𝑚m_{\max}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; furthermore, ideally, mmaxsubscript𝑚m_{\max}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of the length of the rankings. Properties (1) and (2) imply that a ranking evaluation metric is a monotone increasing function of the similarity of two rankings: the more similar two rankings are, the higher the score they get when evaluated using an “interpretable” metric. Having that mmaxsubscript𝑚m_{\max}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of n𝑛nitalic_n is a necessary condition for having an evaluation of rankings independent of n𝑛nitalic_n. However, this is hardly satisfied by any metrics, and only after introducing a normalization score do the metrics satisfy the requirement. Furthermore, the lowest scores are assigned by some metrics to maximally similar pairs of rankings, e.g., error-based metrics. The only metrics, among the ones considered in this paper, automatically satisfying this property are Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ score and Spearmann ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ.

A ranking evaluation metric satisfying the maximal agreement property is also upper-bounded. For the sake of interpretability, we could check whether a metric m𝑚mitalic_m satisfies m⁢(ρ−1,ρ)=mmin𝑚superscript𝜌1𝜌subscript𝑚m(\rho^{-1},\rho)=m_{\min}italic_m ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where ρ−1superscript𝜌1\rho^{-1}italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT indicates the inverse ranking. How do we define the inverse of a ranking? Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfies this property, given that the inverse of one ranking σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ is the ranking τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ assigning the highest position to the last element of the ranking σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ; however, this does not correspond with the inverse of the ranking in the symmetric group. Assessing whether metrics for permutations are humanly interpretable is not new and has already been discussed in [5]. However, then, as well as now, the concept of interpretability lacks a unified definition. Thus, we leave this section open and do not argue further on the interpretability of the considered metrics.

7 Discussion

We explored metrics for comparing and evaluating rankings and analyzed their theoretical properties. All the mentioned metrics are widely used in the literature to evaluate Recommender Systems, Information Retrieval, feature ranking, rank aggregation methods, and items’ score assignments. Each property is highly desirable in some contexts and less in others. The IoI property is desirable in highly sensitive evaluations, where detecting tiny differences among rankings is essential; fair ranking aggregation is an example, where swapping items can make the difference between fair and unfair rankings. Conversely, robustness ensures that small changes influence the evaluations proportionately in a one-to-one fashion. A metric that satisfies both the IoI and the robustness properties ensures contemporaneously that small changes are not overlooked but do not significantly impact the evaluations. The symmetry property ensures that the input rankings have an equal role in the evaluations. This is essential in most domains unless ground truth ranking is available. Note that non-symmetric metrics are also not distances. Rank aggregation is again an example of use for the symmetry property, where the consensus ranking is directly compared with the original rankings provided. Sensitivity is crucial when rankings are not fully explored. This is often the case for Recommender Systems and Information Retrieval techniques’ evaluations. With the same applicability, the stability property ensures trustworthiness in evaluations @⁢k@𝑘@k@ italic_k, which is again highly relevant for Recommender Systems and Information Retrieval techniques. To assure stable evaluations, we recommend considering evaluating the impact @⁢k@𝑘@k@ italic_k and @⁢(k+i)@𝑘𝑖@(k+i)@ ( italic_k + italic_i ) with i𝑖iitalic_i arbitrarily chosen, in particular when k<<nmuch-less-than𝑘𝑛k<<nitalic_k < < italic_n. Finally, the distance property is defined to complete the proposed analysis and highlights the chance that mathematical terms are misused in machine learning contexts. Table 4 summarizes the properties’ descriptions and application domains.

8 Conclusion

Throughout the paper, we explored metrics widely used in the literature to evaluate Recommender Systems, Information Retrieval, feature selection, and rank aggregation methods; rankings are the common output of all these methods. We observed a common presence of non-consistent evaluations of rankings, deriving from the different definitions of the ranking evaluation metrics. Focusing on a mathematical perspective and viewing rankings as elements of symmetric groups and the metrics as functions defined over mathematical groups, we list a set of well-founded mathematical properties for ranking evaluation metrics. The differences among metrics are highlighted by the differences in the satisfiability of the properties, thus grounding the reasons for the inconsistencies in the evaluations. As each property is highly desirable in some contexts and less in others, we summarize the obtained insights that can be of immediate use when looking for an appropriate metric for a specific domain.

Appendix A Proofs

Proof of Proposition 5.2.

MSE, RMSE, MAE, MAPE, R2 score: decomposing the sum in the definition of M⁢S⁢E⁢(σ∘(j⁢k),ν∘(j⁢k))𝑀𝑆𝐸𝜎𝑗𝑘𝜈𝑗𝑘MSE(\sigma\circ(j\ k),\nu\circ(j\ k))italic_M italic_S italic_E ( italic_σ ∘ ( italic_j italic_k ) , italic_ν ∘ ( italic_j italic_k ) ) among addends involving k𝑘kitalic_k or j𝑗jitalic_j and others, it is easy to get to M⁢S⁢E⁢(σ,ν)𝑀𝑆𝐸𝜎𝜈MSE(\sigma,\nu)italic_M italic_S italic_E ( italic_σ , italic_ν ). Similarly, for the other metrics. Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ: it is enough to note that the number of discordant and concordant pairs does not change when applying a swap to both the rankings σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν. Spearmann’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ: similarly to the case of the error based metric, we decompose the sum defining the Spearmann’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ in elements involving j𝑗jitalic_j and k𝑘kitalic_k and others; manipulating the definition, we eventually get the thesis. Unicity: For all the other metrics, finding pairs of rankings providing counterexamples is trivial. For cumulative gain based metrics, the swaps change the association between the position in the ranking and the relevance score. For confusion matrix based metrics, swaps change both the set of relevant and retrieved elements (but not equally); Thus, the evaluation is different after applying swaps in both rankings. ∎

Appendix B Metrics’ definitions

We give some insights on the metrics we mentioned and analyzed throughout the paper; we also properly define here some of the terms and metrics we used.

B.1 Confusion matrix based metrics

Consider a set N𝑁Nitalic_N of n𝑛nitalic_n elements, a subset R⊂N𝑅𝑁{R}\subset Nitalic_R ⊂ italic_N of the relevant elements and a subset S⊂N𝑆𝑁{S}\subset Nitalic_S ⊂ italic_N of the retrieved elements; the confusion matrix, i.e., a C=ℕ2×2𝐶superscriptℕ22C=\mathbb{N}^{2\times 2}italic_C = blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 × 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is defined such that C1,1=|S∩R|subscript𝐶11𝑆𝑅C_{1,1}=|S\cap R|italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_S ∩ italic_R |, C1,2=|S∖R|subscript𝐶12𝑆𝑅C_{1,2}=|S\setminus R|italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_S ∖ italic_R |, C2,1=|R∖S|subscript𝐶21𝑅𝑆C_{2,1}=|R\setminus S|italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_R ∖ italic_S | and C2,2=n−|S∪R|subscript𝐶22𝑛𝑆𝑅C_{2,2}=n-|S\cup R|italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n - | italic_S ∪ italic_R |. Each metric in this group is defined on the sizes of intersections, unions or differences among the sets R,S𝑅𝑆R,Sitalic_R , italic_S and N𝑁Nitalic_N. Given two rankings σ,τ∈Sn𝜎𝜏subscript𝑆𝑛\sigma,\tau\in S_{n}italic_σ , italic_τ ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and two natural numbers j,k<n𝑗𝑘𝑛j,k<nitalic_j , italic_k < italic_n, we can define the set of relevant elements R𝑅{R}italic_R being the first j𝑗jitalic_jths ranked elements by σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and the set of retrieved elements being the first k𝑘kitalic_kths ranked elements by τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, i.e., R=set⁢(σ|j){R}=\text{set}\left(\sigma_{|j}\right)italic_R = set ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and S=set⁢(τ|k){S}=\text{set}\left(\tau_{|k}\right)italic_S = set ( italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

General properties. Defined only on set based quantities, the ordering of the elements appearing before and after j𝑗jitalic_j (or k𝑘kitalic_k) is irrelevant. Some of these metrics represent a powerful tool for evaluating and comparing rankings. Their strength is well founded on the simplicity and interpretability of the definitions; however, one should consider more sophisticated evaluation metrics when the interest is in the rankings rather than the ability to retrieve the relevant elements.

We shortly define the used metrics and, for sake of readability, we drop the notation (σ,τ)𝜎𝜏(\sigma,\tau)( italic_σ , italic_τ ); we consider k=j𝑘𝑗k=jitalic_k = italic_j throughout the manuscript. B.2 Correlation measures

They explicitly rely on the correlation among the two rankings and are often used in statistical applications. In contrast to confusion matrix based metrics, they consider all the length of the rankings. Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ coefficient and Spearmann ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ consider the permutation of the elements over arrays of length n𝑛nitalic_n [16]. The Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ coefficient is based on the definition of concordant and discordant couples (two elements i,j𝑖𝑗i,jitalic_i , italic_j are concordant in σ,τ𝜎𝜏\sigma,\tauitalic_σ , italic_τ if σ⁢(i)<σ⁢(j)𝜎𝑖𝜎𝑗\sigma(i)<\sigma(j)italic_σ ( italic_i ) < italic_σ ( italic_j ) and τ⁢(i)<τ⁢(j)𝜏𝑖𝜏𝑗\tau(i)<\tau(j)italic_τ ( italic_i ) < italic_τ ( italic_j ) or the same holds with >>>). In particular,

τ=|{concordant pairs}|−|{discordant pairs}|(n2)𝜏concordant pairsdiscordant pairsbinomial𝑛2\tau=\frac{|\{\text{concordant pairs}\}|-|\{\text{discordant pairs}\}|}{\binom% {n}{2}}italic_τ = divide start_ARG | { concordant pairs } | - | { discordant pairs } | end_ARG start_ARG ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_ARG

Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ varies in the interval [−1,+1]11[-1,+1][ - 1 , + 1 ]: τ=1𝜏1\tau=1italic_τ = 1 if σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ agree perfectly while τ=−1𝜏1\tau=-1italic_τ = - 1 if one ordering is the reverse of the other. Furthermore, if σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ and ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν are independent then τ≈0𝜏0\tau\approx 0italic_τ ≈ 0.
The Spearmann score is defined as the Pearson correlation coefficient and in the case that the n𝑛nitalic_n ranks are distinct integers, it can be computed using the formula

r=1−6⁢∑i=1n(σ⁢(i)−τ⁢(i))2n⁢(n2−1).𝑟16superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscript𝜎𝑖𝜏𝑖2𝑛superscript𝑛21r=1-\frac{6\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\sigma(i)-\tau(i))^{2}}{n(n^{2}-1)}.italic_r = 1 - divide start_ARG 6 ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_σ ( italic_i ) - italic_τ ( italic_i ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) end_ARG .

As a drawback, correlation based metrics assign the same importance to the first part as to the last part of the rankings; as they equally evaluate exchanges in the first-ranked items and in the ending part of the ranking, they do not properly fit with evaluating orderings. Both Spearmann’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ and Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ directly penalize swaps of ’further located’ elements; Considering two rankings σ,τ𝜎𝜏\sigma,\tauitalic_σ , italic_τ that differ for one single swap (i⁢j)𝑖𝑗(i\ j)( italic_i italic_j ), if i,j𝑖𝑗i,jitalic_i , italic_j are far in the rankings, then they will evaluate their difference as being bigger as if they would be nearer.

B.3 Cumulative gain based metrics

Constructed with the specific aim of evaluating whether the ordering of relevant elements is respected, they use relevance scores assigned to each element. We assume that the relevance score of an element i𝑖iitalic_i is represented by all different relevant scores; in particular, we consider reli=σ⁢(i)subscriptrel𝑖𝜎𝑖\text{rel}_{i}=\sigma(i)rel start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( italic_i ) allowing to fairly compare with other metrics that do not have access to relevance scores of items, but only their position. We initially considered assigning reli=1subscriptrel𝑖1\text{rel}_{i}=1rel start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 to all relevant elements; however, this immediately would imply that DCG and nDCG do not satisfy the IoI property as relevant elements are indistinguishable. The Discounted cumulative gain DCG assumes that highly relevant items appearing lower in a search result list should be penalized as the graded relevance value is scaled to be logarithmically proportional to the position of the item; the definition reads DCG=∑i=1nσ⁢(i)log2⁡(i+1)DCGsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝜎𝑖subscript2𝑖1\text{DCG}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{\sigma(i)}{\log_{2}(i+1)}DCG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_σ ( italic_i ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i + 1 ) end_ARG. The Normalized discounted cumulative gain nDCG is a normalization of the DCG through the normalization coefficient IDCG, computed by sorting all elements by their relative relevance, and producing the maximum possible DCG. The two metrics nDCG and DCG are linearly equivalent; Thus, as Figure 1 already empirically showed, there are no inconsistencies among them.

Strictly connected to the cumulative gain metrics is the Mean Reciprocal Rank MRR that evaluates the position of each relevant element in the ranking and computes the average of the reciprocal positional ranking of the results, i.e., MRR=1|R|⁢∑i=1|R|1σ⁢(i)MRR1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑅1𝜎𝑖\text{MRR}=\frac{1}{|{R}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|{R}|}\frac{1}{\sigma(i)}MRR = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_R | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_R | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ ( italic_i ) end_ARG; thus, it is the relevance scores’ harmonic mean. The meanRank is defined as meanRank⁢(σ)=1|R|⁢∑i=1|R|σ⁢(i)meanRank𝜎1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑅𝜎𝑖\text{meanRank}(\sigma)=\frac{1}{|{R}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|{R}|}{\sigma(i)}meanRank ( italic_σ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_R | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_R | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( italic_i ) and the GMR as the geometric mean of the first k𝑘kitalic_k ranked elements of the ranking σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ.

B.3.1 Error based metrics

Although meant to evaluate continuous and discrete labels, error-based metrics found application in evaluating rankings. They do not consider the ordering of items but compute the difference in each position, sum it all together, and return an average. We will briefly provide the definitions of each metric in this section.
